post_text:
Not sure what to do? Keep it simple:

1. Read everyday. Reading is the basis of learning. Cereal boxes, comic books, magazines, recipes, and instruction manuals all count as reading!

2. Practice math fact. Adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing are the foundation of all math.

3. Count money. In a world of debit and credit cards, kids of all ages need practice counting money (especially coins).

4. Practice telling time. Even older kids struggle with reading clocks.

5. Write. Writing is a brain exercise that helps the writer to be observant and organize thoughts.

As the saying goes, use it or lose it!

post_text: Grade 5 students in HCGS's Room 24 recently completed a multi-period science lab activity called Separating a Salt Solution. The activity is part of the Full-Option Science System (FOSS) Structure and Properties of Matter unit. Students added a measured amount of salt to a measured amount of water to make a solution. Next, they compared the total mass of a mixture to the mass of its parts to infer that the "invisible salt" was still present. Lastly, the seven cooperative-learning groups evaporated the salt solutions to reclaim the salt as crystals. [KS Science Standard 5-PS1-4] 👩‍🔬👨‍🔬🤔
